definition: to go too far (in word or deed)/over the top
to cross/to go over/to pass (time)/to celebrate (a holiday)/to live/to get along/excessively/too-
fire/urgent/ammunition/fiery or flaming/internal heat (Chinese medicine)/hot (popular)/classifier for military units (old)/Kangxi radical 86

sentences.english: It was one of the few signs of feistiness from China all afternoon.
sentences.chinese: 這是整個下午中國隊爲數不多的幾次過火表現之一。

sentences.english: I overdid it in the gym and hurt my back.
sentences.chinese: 我在健身房練得過火了，結果弄傷了背。

sentences.english: You must have overplayed your hand.
sentences.chinese: 你一定是做得太過火了。

sentences.english: Then focus on your strengths but don’t overdo it.
sentences.chinese: 利用你的長處但是不要做的過火。

sentences.english: I think it is a good thing, but don'tever overdo it.
sentences.chinese: 我認爲這挺好的，但是不要做得太過火了。

sentences.english: Joe played his part to a fault and looked silly before the audience.
sentences.chinese: 喬的表演太過火，現觀衆面前顯得傻頭傻腦。

sentences.english: Don't go overboard, always take a loof at your future financial obligations first.
sentences.chinese: 不要太過火，始終以楊木爲你未來的財政義務。

sentences.english: Finally still a little do far, lose too much, change too malicious.
sentences.chinese: 終於還是有點做的過火了，丟掉的太多，變化的太狠。

sentences.english: The fish was overdone and very dry.
That means that pay on time and not too far into the debt.
sentences.chinese: 那準時意味付帳和不做的過火入債務。

sentences.english: Still, it's possible to go too far.
sentences.chinese: 不過，還是有可能做得太過火。

sentences.english: Before, I could never sit by a fire, but now I have my own charcoal to burn.
sentences.chinese: 過去我從來沒有烤過火，現在我有炭燒。

sentences.english: The actor overplayed  the role of Hamlet.
sentences.chinese: 那名演員把哈姆雷特的角色演得過火了。

sentences.english: She took particular care not to overcook the meat.
sentences.chinese: 她特別小心不把肉烹調過火。

sentences.english: At what point does he think having cosmetic procedures can go too far?
sentences.chinese: 要到什麼程度他纔會認爲醫療美容做得太過火了？

definition: to burn/to cook/to stew/to bake/to roast/to heat/to boil (tea, water etc)/fever/to run a temperature/(coll.) to let things go to one's head
to recognize people (of babies)/to be able to tell people apart
to soar/to gallop/to prance/to turn over/to vacate/to clear
as one wishes/as one pleases/at random/negligent/casual/wanton
at the minimum/at the very least
inconvenient/troublesome/annoying/to trouble or bother sb/to put sb to trouble
to choke (because of swallowing the wrong way)
to irritate the nose/to choke (of smoke, smell etc)/pungent/(coll.) (Tw) to shout at sb/to scold/to speak out against sb
